questions.text: In the current scenario treatment for urea cycle disorder is available. Administration of phenylbutyrate can decrease ammonia formation, which amino acid provides ammonia to phenylbutyrate.
questions.solution:
Urea cycle is the major disposal form of amino groups derived from amino acids, 90% of the nitrogen containing components of urine. Hyperammonemia is either by acquired or genetic condition. Acquired causes like alcoholism leading to damaged liver, fatty liver and cirrhosis, commonly seen in adults. Genetic cause including deficiency of enzymes of Urea cycle like CPS 1 deficiency, NAGS Deficiency, OTC deficiency etc.

Ammonia transport from peripheral tissue to liver for conversion to urea involves Glutamine Synthase to combine ammonia with Glutamate. Thus glutamine provides non toxic storage and transport of ammonia. In urea cycle disorders, use of Phenylbutyrate is one of the treatment options.

Phenylbutyrate is converted into phenylacetate which combines with Glutamine to form Phenylacetylglutamine. It contains two nitrogen atoms, excreted in Urine thereby clearance of Nitrogenous waste.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A (Arginine):

  • Arginine is involved in the urea cycle as a substrate for arginase, producing urea and ornithine.
  • It does not donate ammonia for phenylbutyrate conjugation.
  • Arginine supplementation is sometimes used for argininosuccinate synthetase (ASS) or argininosuccinate lyase (ASL) deficiencies, but it is not the key provider of ammonia for phenylbutyrate therapy.

Choice C (Aspartate):

  • Aspartate donates nitrogen in the urea cycle by contributing an amino group to form argininosuccinate.
  • However, it does not contribute directly to phenylbutyrate-mediated ammonia removal.

Choice D (Glycine):

  • Glycine is involved in alternative nitrogen excretion pathways, such as conjugation with benzoate to form hippuric acid, another treatment for hyperammonemia.
  • However, it is not the primary donor for phenylbutyrate conjugation.

Key Takeaway

  • Glutamate is the key amino acid that provides ammonia in the urea cycle by forming glutamine, which then reacts with phenylacetate to form phenylacetylglutamine, facilitating ammonia excretion.
  • Phenylbutyrate therapy is effective in urea cycle disorders by bypassing the defective enzymatic steps and removing excess nitrogen in a non-urea pathway.

questions.text:
Which among the following are appropriate techniques for chromosomal aneuploidy?
a. In situ hybridization
b. Conventional cytogenetics
c. Sanger sequencing
d. Polymerase Chain Reaction
questions.solution:
Genomic instability is frequently used to refer to two abnormalities seen in many cancer cells: microsatellite instability (MSI) and chromosomal instability (CIN). CIN refers to gain or loss of chromosomes caused by abnormalities of chromosomal segregation during mitosis.

An important aspect of CIN is aneuploidy, a very common feature of solid tumors. Aneuploidy exists when the chromosomal number of a cell is not a multiple of the haploid number. The degree of aneuploidy often correlates with a poor prognosis suggesting that abnormalities of chromosomal seggregation contribute to tumor progression by increasing genetic diversity

Using highly sensitive fluorescent labeled hybridization probes, specific gene sequences can be mapped, or "painted," within the nuclei of human cells, even without polytene chromosome formation, using fluorescence in situ hybridization, or FISH techniques

Conventional Cytogenetics technique involves the study of Chromosomes under Microscope - Karyotyping. The analysis helps to identify large chromosomal abnormalities such as aneuploidy.

Sanger Sequencing - It uses Chain termination to identify the exact sequence of nucleotide in a DNA molecule

PCR - It amplifies specific DNA sequences. Quantify target nucleic acid sequence within a sample. Also used for Aneuploidy detection.

Key Takeaway

  • Chromosomal aneuploidy can be detected using multiple techniques, including FISH, karyotyping, Sanger sequencing, and PCR.
  • FISH and conventional cytogenetics are the gold standard for detecting large chromosomal abnormalities.
  • PCR and sequencing methods provide molecular-level detection of aneuploidy-related genetic variations.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Tryptophan is an amino acid which is converted to serotonin and then Melatonin. Thus tryptophan is essential amino acid and precursor for synthesis of Melatonin

Histidine amino acid is in the presence of Histidine Decarboxylase converted into Histamine.

Norepinephrine is synthesized from Tyrosine. Tyrosine in presence of tyrosine Hydroxylase converted into L DOPA. Then L DOPA is converted into dopamine. Finally Dopamine is hydroxylated to form Norepinephrine.

Glutathione is a tripeptide composed of Glutamate, Cystine and Glycine.

Key Takeaway

  • Melatonin originates from Tryptophan.
  • Histamine originates from Histidine.
  • Norepinephrine originates from Tyrosine.
  • Glutathione contains Cysteine as a key component

questions.text: Nutritional deficiency of Copper, required by lysyl oxidase which is an important key step for the formation of covalent cross links in collagen synthesis gives rise to which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Menke's Disease is an X linked Recessive condition. Mutation of ATP 7 A gene leading to impaired transport of Copper from small intestine to liver leading to copper Deficiency.

Copper is required for Lysyl oxidase for formation of Cross linking in collagen synthesis. This will provide strength and rigidity for college. In menke's disease patients have Kinky Hair also known as kinky hair syndrome. Other Symptoms like failure to thrive, Neurodegenerative Symptoms, recurrent infections.

Scurvy is caused by vitamin C Deficiency leading to defective collagen synthesis due to defective hydroxylation of proline and lysine.

Ehlers- Danlos syndrome - Group of disorders affecting collagen structure or production

Scoliosis - Structural Deformity of Spine

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice B (Scurvy) - Incorrect

  • Scurvy is caused by Vitamin C deficiency, not copper deficiency.
  • Vitamin C is required for the hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues in collagen synthesis.
  • Deficiency leads to fragile blood vessels, poor wound healing, and bleeding gums, which are different from Menkes Disease symptoms.

Choice C (Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome) - Incorrect

  • Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (EDS) is a group of genetic disorders affecting collagen synthesis or structure, leading to hyperelastic skin, joint hypermobility, and fragile tissues.
  • Some types of EDS are associated with defective lysyl hydroxylase or collagen-processing enzymes, but not due to copper deficiency.

Choice D (Scoliosis) - Incorrect

  • Scoliosis is a structural deformity of the spine, often idiopathic or caused by neuromuscular conditions, congenital defects, or connective tissue disorders.
  • It is not directly related to copper deficiency or lysyl oxidase dysfunction.

Key Takeaway

  • Menkes Disease results from copper deficiency, leading to impaired lysyl oxidase activity and defective collagen cross-linking.
  • Scurvy is due to Vitamin C deficiency, affecting collagen hydroxylation.
  • Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome is a genetic disorder affecting collagen structure.
  • Scoliosis is a spinal deformity, not related to copper metabolism.

choices.text: Decreased action of LPL with increased action of HSL
Decreased action of LPL with decreased action of HSL
Increased action of LPL with increased action of HSL
Increased action of LPL with decreased action of HSL

questions.text: In a patient with diabetes mellitus the liver produces more triacylglycerol and VLDL. What is the cause for the same?
questions.solution:
In uncontrolled Diabetes, relative or absolute deficiency of Insulin is present. Lipoprotein Lipase and Hormone Sensitive Lipase have their actions in fasting state and Fed state respectively. In the Absence of Insulin, the action of hormone sensitive lipase is increases as Insulin has inhibitory action on it. It leads to breakdown of Lipids into TG and VLDL and their concentration increases in blood.

The Simultaneous role of Lipoprotein lipase is to convert TG, VLDL and Chylomicrons into Free Fatty acid for energy or storage purposes. In Absence of Insulin Action of Lipoprotein lipase is decreased so increase in level of TG & VLDL.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice B (Decreased action of LPL with decreased action of HSL) - Incorrect

  • HSL activity actually increases in diabetes due to loss of insulin's inhibitory effect.
  • If both LPL and HSL were decreased, there would be reduced lipolysis in adipose tissue, which is not the case in diabetes.

Choice C (Increased action of LPL with increased action of HSL) - Incorrect

  • LPL activity decreases in diabetes because insulin is required for its activation.
  • If LPL increased, there would be enhanced clearance of TG and VLDL, which contradicts the hypertriglyceridemia seen in diabetes.

Choice D (Increased action of LPL with decreased action of HSL) - Incorrect

  • HSL activity is actually increased due to lack of insulin inhibition.
  • LPL does not increase in diabetes, leading to TG and VLDL accumulation.

Key Takeaway

  • Diabetes mellitus leads to increased TG and VLDL levels due to decreased Lipoprotein Lipase (LPL) activityand increased Hormone-Sensitive Lipase (HSL) activity.
  • LPL requires insulin for activation, while HSL is inhibited by insulin.
  • Insulin deficiency promotes fat breakdown (lipolysis), increases free fatty acids, and enhances liver TG and VLDL production, contributing to diabetic dyslipidemia.

questions.text:
Enzyme(s) used in recombinant DNA technology are:
a. Isomerase
b. Phosphatase
c. Terminal transferase
d. Crispr cas9
questions.solution:
In Recombinant DNA Technology Phosphatase, Terminal Transferase and Crispr Cas 9 are used.

Use of Recombinant DNA Technology is in Insulin & Growth Hormone Production, Gene Therapy and disease Mechanism.

Phosphatase dephosphorylates 5' ends of RNA and DNA. It is primarily used for the removal of phosphate groups and also used to prevent self ligation.

Terminal Transferase catalyzes addition of Nucleotides to the 3' end of DNA .

CRISPR CAS 9 acts on RNA directed Nuclease. Cas 9 and Endonuclease are components of it. It causes double stranded DNA break, allowing Modification to the genomic DNA.

Isomerase catalyzes structural rearrangement of Molecules.

Key Takeaway

  • Phosphatase, Terminal Transferase, and CRISPR-Cas9 are key enzymes used in Recombinant DNA Technology.
  • Isomerases are not involved in rDNA technology as they do not modify or manipulate DNA sequences.

questions.text: Cytochrome C oxidase present in the electron transport chain can be blocked by all except:
questions.solution:
In electron Transport chain, blocking electron transfer by any one of these inhibitors stops electron flow from substrate to oxygen (O2) because the reactions of the electron transport chain are tightly coupled like meshed gears.

Cytochrome a + a3 - Cytochrome Complex IV is the only electron carrier in which the heme iron has an available coordination site that can react directly with O2, also called cytochrome c Oxidase. Carbon Monoxide, Cyanide and hydrogen sulphide all are inhibitors of Cytochrome C oxidase.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A (Carbon monoxide) - Incorrect

  • Carbon monoxide (CO) competes with oxygen for binding at the heme a3-CuB center of cytochrome c oxidase, thereby inhibiting electron transport and reducing ATP synthesis.

Choice B (Cyanide) - Incorrect

  • Cyanide (CN-) binds irreversibly to the Fe³+ in cytochrome c oxidase, preventing electron transfer to O2 and leading to cellular asphyxiation.

Choice D (Hydrogen sulfide) - Incorrect

  • Hydrogen sulfide (H2S) is a potent inhibitor of cytochrome c oxidase, blocking oxidative phosphorylation and leading to cellular hypoxia.

Key Takeaway

  • Cytochrome c oxidase (Complex IV) can be inhibited by CO, CN-, and H2S, but NOT significantly by NO.

Nitric oxide (NO) does interact with the respiratory chain but does not cause the same level of irreversible inhibition as the other molecules.

choices.text: If tourniquet is needed, tie and release as soon as sample is collected
Making a fist is not recommended
Staying immobilised for a long period of time increases calcium levels

questions.text: While collecting a blood sample for serum calcium which is easily alterable. Which of the following should be prevented to measure it accurately?
questions.solution:
During Serum calcium estimation, Collecting blood sample after exercise needs to be avoided.

Prolonged tourniquet use leads to increase in Calcium level due to hemoconcentration and alters values. Similarly if you are asking for making a fist during collection , it can increase ionized calcium level. During prolonged immobilization also bone resorption may increase calcium level that needs to be counted during treatment.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A (If tourniquet is needed, tie and release as soon as sample is collected) - Incorrect

  • Prolonged tourniquet application leads to hemoconcentration, falsely increasing serum calcium levels.
  • However, brief tourniquet use does not significantly alter calcium measurement.

Choice C (Making a fist is not recommended) - Incorrect

  • Clenching the fist during venipuncture can cause:
    • Increased ionized calcium levels due to muscle contraction.
    • Acid-base changes, affecting calcium binding to albumin.
  • However, this effect is minor compared to post-exercise alterations.

Choice D (Staying immobilized for a long period of time increases calcium levels) - Incorrect

  • Prolonged immobilization can lead to bone resorption, increasing serum calcium.
  • However, this is not an immediate concern for blood collection and primarily affects patients with prolonged bed rest or conditions like osteoporosis.

Key Takeaway

  • Serum calcium measurement should be performed under standardized conditions to avoid physiological variations.
  • Blood should not be collected immediately after exercise to prevent falsely elevated calcium levels.
